title: Marvel's Samuel L Jackson responds to Martin Scorsese comments
text:
Samuel served the truth bombs (Picture: Getty Images)

Now Samuel L Jackson has waded into the Martin Scorsese debate, as he defended Marvel movies.

Legendary director Martin had compared the Marvel Cinematic Universe’s offerings to that of a theme park, slamming them as ‘not cinema’.

Seems while the likes of James Gunn and Avengers director Joss Whedon has added their two cents, Samuel wanted a piece of the pie.

However, instead of sharing some emotional sentiment about the thing, he just served the cold hard facts.

It isn’t going to stop the MCU from churning out those people pleasing pictures.

Speaking to Variety on the red carpet of the grand opening of Tyler Perry’s new studio in Atlanta, he was asked for his opinion on the criticism.

‘I mean that’s like saying Bugs Bunny ain’t funny. Films are films. Everybody doesn’t like his stuff either,’ he said, just channelling all the Nick Fury.

He added: ‘Everybody’s got an opinion, so I mean it’s okay.

‘Ain’t going to stop nobody from making movies.’

Martin Scorsese isn’t a Marvel fan (Picture: FADEL SENNA/AFP/Getty Images)

No it won’t.

It comes after Martin previously admitted he’d tried and failed to enjoy the Marvel movies, which include money-spinning franchises like Infinity War and Endgame, Guardians of the Galaxy and Captain America.

He shared: ‘I don’t see them. I tried, you know? But that’s not cinema.

‘Honestly, the closest I can think of them, as well made as they are, with actors doing the best they can under the circumstances, is theme parks.

‘It isn’t the cinema of human beings trying to convey emotional, psychological experiences to another human being.’

Avengers director Joss too has leapt into action this weekend, after GOTG director James also spoke his opinion on the matter.

The 55-year-old director – who helmed The Avengers in 2012 – initially tweeted Scorsese’s statement, typing: ‘It isn’t the cinema of human beings trying to convey emotional, psychological experiences to another human being.’

Advertisement

Then, he discussed Martin’s claims in reference to filmmaker James and the GOTG franchise.

He continued: ‘I first think of @JamesGunn, how his heart & guts are packed into GOTG. I revere Marty, & I do see his point, but…

‘Well there’s a reason why “I’m always angry”. (sic)

Over the weekend James said: ‘Martin Scorsese is one of my 5 favorite living filmmakers. I was outraged when people picketed The Last Temptation of Christ without having seen the film. I’m saddened that he’s now judging my films in the same way.’

He went on to add: ‘That said, I will always love Scorsese, be grateful for his contribution to cinema, and can’t wait to see The Irishman.’
